title: Couple lose 14st between them after getting 'his and hers' gastric bands
text:

It is hardly the most romantic way to celebrate 25 years of marriage.

Louise and Derek Mills had originally planned to go on a Caribbean cruise.

Instead, he cancelled the ­holiday and used the £8,000 he saved to buy her gastric surgery to help her lose weight.

Six months later, Louise was so overjoyed with the results she spent £4,000 on a gastric balloon procedure for him.

The operations have helped the couple lose more than 14 stone between them.

Louise, 50, said: “It doesn’t sound romantic but it’s rekindled our marriage in a way we never could’ve imagined.

“Derek’s showered me with gifts over the years and loves spoiling me. Jewellery, gorgeous clothes, you name it, he’s the most kind, generous person.

“When close friends and family heard Derek was paying for me to have gastric surgery they thought it was insulting, but nothing could’ve been further from the truth. It was the most loving, thoughtful present in the world.

“We’d dreamed about going on that Caribbean cruise for years but we agreed weight loss surgery would be a gift for life, while a cruise would just last a few days.”

The mum of three is now a svelte 8st 5lb after weighing 15st 7lb at her heaviest.

“It’s like we’ve gone in a time machine back to when we were first married,” she added.We seriously fancy each other again, which is something you don’t often hear from a couple in their 50s who’ve been married a quarter of a century.

(Image: Tim Merry)

“Our sex life is great, my depression has completely lifted, and our kids constantly tell us how happy we seem.”

Louise, who is a full-time carer to their 28-year-old daughter Laura who has Down’s syndrome, started piling on pounds when her mother died of cancer in 2010.

Louise could not stick to any diet she tried.

“Mum and I were best friends, and when she died I sunk into a massive depression. I found ­solace in food, secretly bingeing on massive bars of chocolate when everyone was asleep.

“My depression left me unable to deal with the fact that I was killing myself.”

(Image: Tim Merry)

Louise also cooked high-calorie meals for the family in Hempstead, Kent, such as fillet steak with mashed potato, huge casseroles, mushrooms in garlic butter, and creamy puddings.

Soon Derek’s shirt size grew from a size XL to XXXL and the previously active couple spent ­evenings grazing on junk food on the sofa.

In 2017 Louise tried for months to slim for her stepdaughter’s wedding – but got nowhere.

“The idea of looking like a blob in those wedding photos horrified me but month by month I tried and failed with yet another diet,” she said.

“On their big day in July last year I was the same size 20, weighing 15st 7lb and I hated myself more than ever.

“If I didn’t get healthy soon Laura would lose her mum and without me I didn’t know what she’d do.

“It was a vicious cycle of guilt, despair and depression.”

(Image: Tim Merry)

Inspired by a friend’s sister who’d had success with weight loss surgery, Louise looked ­online – and baulked at the cost.

“I knew we had our dream cruise coming up in a few months, so money was tight, but when I opened up to Derek about how down I was, he didn’t hesitate for one second.

He told Louise: “If money can’t buy you happiness, what’s the point?” and within minutes was cancelling the cruise.

She said: “Of course I knew the results of any surgery are never guaranteed, but I also knew I’d die soon if I didn’t try this. I gave Derek the biggest hug ever.”

Louise went to private Benenden Hospital near Cranbrook, Kent, where bariatric surgeon Ahmed Hamouda recommended a gastric sleeve. It means removing a part of the stomach to reduce its size.

She had the surgery on August 1 last year and by the end of October was down to a size 12, the same as when she and Derek wed in 1994.

(Image: Tim Merry)

“I simply didn’t feel hungry and within weeks knew I wasn’t going to die any more. That sense of euphoria was incredible, like I’d been let out of prison.”

Within weeks Louise was exercising for the first time in over a decade – going to ­kickboxing and circuit classes and riding her bicycle.

But while she was “bouncing around like Tigger”, 19-stone Derek was stuck in the same rut.

“I was slightly oblivious to the fact that the slimmer I got, the worse Derek felt about his weight,” she said.

“I was so overjoyed with my new life that I just wanted to return the incredible gesture as a Christmas present. I had some savings and was even prepared to put it on credit if I had to.”

That Christmas – without knowing Louise had put a voucher in a card for a consultation with Mr Hamouda – Derek refused to sit next to Louise for photographs.

(Image: Tim Merry)

“He just felt so big next to me, it was truly painful for him. But I knew that that evening he’d be over the moon with what 2019 had in store for him.”

When Derek saw the voucher, he told her it was too expensive.

“I told Derek that I loved him more than any amount of money, any cruise, and I wouldn’t hear him say no,” she said.

In the new year Mr Hamouda advised Derek to have a gastric balloon. This is a non-surgical option where a soft silicon balloon is inflated in the stomach to make you feel full quicker.

A month later Derek, a self-employed engineer, had it fitted in a simple 30-minute procedure and his weight fell quickly.

“By then I was cooking much healthier options at home for myself, which I was happy to double-up for Derek,” Louise said. “Within a few weeks I could see him happier, like he knew this was the start of something incredibly exciting.”

The couple splashed out on new bicycles, enjoying long ­country rides in the evening and at weekends.

By August he had lost six stone, dropping from a 47 to a 34-inch waist. He is now down to 12 stone after shedding seven stone altogether.

Derek, 57, who has four kids from his first marriage, said: “Like most blokes I like spoiling my wife but I hate the idea of someone wasting money on me. But Louise wasn’t going to budge with her Christmas present.”

With a work medical coming up in the spring, he also feared he might be deemed a liability and lose his income.

“There’s also a history of heart attacks and stroke in my family, so it made sense to follow Louise’s lead.”

“We’ve worked out we’ll save the £12,000 we spent on our procedures in two years, and how we feel now about each other and life is better than any cruise.”
description: Louise and Derek Mills cancelled an £8,000 Caribbean cruise to spend the money on gastric surgery for Louise - then six months later they splashed out £4,000 on a gastric balloon procedure for Derek
